channel.title: Please test my game/site out!
channel.description:
i have been making a mafia style text-based mmorpg im in some need of people just having a little go and see if they can find any bugs,errors,glitches.. even if they wanna try some sql injections i dont mind... i need this site a secure as possible!!!
please come and talk a look and tell me what you think!!!
NOTE - When registing lease use valid email as validation is still required.
[url=http://www.mafiakillerz.com]www.mafiakillerz.com[/url]

item.title: Please test my game/site out!
item.dc:creator: @runescape3dude runescape3dude
item.description:
@runescape3dude wrote:

it looks like someone fucked your site already?

Read full topic

item.title: Please test my game/site out!
item.dc:creator: @inertia inertia
item.description:
@inertia wrote:

[quote=“cane, post:5, topic:326555”]I’m pretty sure this is not yours, I have seen this template been used before.[/quote]That’s pretty pathetic if he had to steal that.

Hints and tips!!!

[code]Unfortunatly mafiakillerz is very buggy when being played via Internet Explorer.
Please use one of the following to play mafiakillerz:

  • Google Chrome
  • Mozilla FireFox[/code]

Yeh just make it show that when you’re using IE, instead of insulting everyone’s intelligence.

Fix spelling!

Also I accidentally intentionally signed up with an invalid email address, so tried to register the account again with a real address once I realised it had to be valid and failed because I had already registered via my IP. Use AJAX checking (mx records n all that jazz) so it’s clear to idiots like me that we have to use a real address, and make account activation expire after 12 hours and require them to re-register the account. You should also allow people to change the email address they originally provided with username+password authentication.

Speaking of IP addresses, remember most of your userbase will be on a public IP pool so while there’s not much chance a different user with the same IP address will play your game, it can happen - especially if you’re thinking of eventually selling the software (or any other software) to a company.

Read full topic
